title: Penetrating Neck Injury
diagnosis_topic: Zone II neck stab wound with potential vascular and aerodigestive injury
setup_script: “A 40-year-old man presents after being stabbed in the right side of his neck. There is active bleeding controlled with direct pressure. He is speaking in a hoarse voice. How would you proceed with this patient?”

dynamic_flow.reply: Patient remains alert; airway is patent but intubation equipment should be prepared in case of deterioration.
BP 110/70 mmHg, HR 105 bpm, RR 22/min, SpO₂ 97%.
Wound located in Zone II anterior to the sternocleidomastoid; no expanding hematoma; tracheal deviation absent.
Patient denies dysphagia or hematemesis; reports hoarse voice and pain localized to wound.

dynamic_flow.trigger: If resident orders CT angiography of the neck
dynamic_flow.reply: Shows near circumferential laceration of external jugular vein without arterial injury; esophagus and trachea intact.

dynamic_flow.trigger: If resident delays imaging and exploration
dynamic_flow.reply: Patient develops an expanding hematoma with airway compromise; SpO₂ drops to 82%.

dynamic_flow.trigger: If resident performs emergent airway intervention
dynamic_flow.reply: Airway secured with endotracheal intubation; oxygen saturation improves to 99%.

dynamic_flow.trigger: If resident consults vascular surgery and otolaryngology
dynamic_flow.reply: Plan made for operative exploration and ligation of injured vein.

dynamic_flow.trigger: If resident discusses selective vs. mandatory exploration
dynamic_flow.reply: Hemodynamically stable Zone II injuries may undergo CT angiography to guide management.
Not necessary given CT findings but could be considered if suspicion for esophageal injury persists.

dynamic_flow.trigger: If resident explores the wound surgically
dynamic_flow.reply: Operative findings confirm external jugular vein injury, no arterial or aerodigestive injury. Vein is ligated successfully.

dynamic_flow.trigger: If resident is asked to describe operative steps
dynamic_flow.reply: Please describe your approach to surgical exploration and control of the vascular injury.
Monitor for bleeding, airway compromise, wound infection, and vocal cord dysfunction.
Postoperative laryngoscopy shows mild left vocal cord paresis, likely recurrent laryngeal nerve neuropraxia.

dynamic_flow.trigger: If resident does not address postoperative complication
dynamic_flow.reply: Patient later presents with stridor on POD 1, requiring ENT re-evaluation.

critical_decision_points: Airway management and hemodynamic stabilization in penetrating neck injuries
Use of CT angiography for evaluation of Zone II injuries
Recognition of indications for operative exploration vs. observation

resident_feedback_template:
Strengths: You demonstrated strong diagnostic reasoning by recognizing the implications of a Zone II penetrating neck injury. Your airway management preparation was appropriate, and you effectively incorporated imaging and surgical decision-making. Communication of your plan was clear and confident.
Areas for Improvement: Earlier recognition of the potential for rapid airway compromise would improve clinical urgency. Incorporation of structured postoperative surveillance, including vocal cord evaluation, would strengthen your management.
